questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother 2 days after developing a rash. The mother reports that the redness appeared suddenly about an hour after bathing. Two weeks ago, the patient was diagnosed with a skin infection and was treated with penicillin V. She has been otherwise healthy but has missed several well-child examinations. She lives with her mother, who recently lost her job. The patient's maternal aunt has systemic lupus erythematosus. During the visit, the mother expresses frustration, stating that her daughter "never listens and is hard to control.” The patient’s temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 108/62 mm Hg. She appears quiet and withdrawn. Physical examination shows sharply delineated erythema from above the knees to just above the umbilicus, with sparing of the buttocks. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Multiple injuries in different stages of healing
Malar rash with sparing of the nasolabial folds

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with sharply delineated erythema on the lower extremities and abdomen with sparing of the buttocks (doughnut pattern) in combination with sharp burn borders and no splash marks, suggesting a scald injury due to forced immersion in hot water. During forced immersion, the victim reflexively flexes their legs, leading to characteristic sparing of flexor surfaces (see “Overview of scalds” table). Additional concerning findings in this scenario include the delayed presentation (seeking medical care 2 days later), missed well-child visits, and the mother's expressed frustration with her child.

Children who experience physical abuse often present with multiple injuries in different stages of healing. Risk factors for perpetrating child maltreatment include history of experiencing childhood abuse or domestic violence, psychiatric conditions, and socioeconomic factors such as recent job loss and financial hardship. Physicians are legally obligated to report suspected child abuse to Child Protective Services, even if it requires breaking patient-physician confidentiality.

B) INCORRECT:

Dermatographism is seen in some patients with urticaria. Patients with certain forms of physical urticaria (e.g., aquagenic urticaria, cholinergic urticaria) may present with sharply-demarcated erythematous lesions (rather than uniform erythema) that appear after a bath, as seen here. However, these lesions tend to be raised (wheals) and are intensely itchy. Moreover, wheals associated with most physical urticaria usually disappear within an hour after the stimulus is removed; the persistence of the lesion for two days indicates a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Well-circumscribed, partially confluent erythematous lesions are visible on the torso and limbs.

This is the typical presentation of urticaria (hives).

C) INCORRECT:

A positive Nikolsky sign can be seen in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). Although this patient does have a rash, it is sharply demarcated, involving only the lower part of the body, with sparing of the flexor surfaces, which is not typical of the diffuse rash seen in SSSS. Furthermore, she lacks other signs of infection (e.g., fever, malaise) that occur with SSSS.
Image Description:

There is diffuse erythema of all visible skin. Large ruptured blisters are visible on the left lower leg, and a large flaccid unruptured blister can be seen on the left buttock.

D) INCORRECT:

Malar rash with sparing of the nasolabial folds can be seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE typically affects women of child-bearing age and manifests with other rheumatological symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, myalgias, arthritis). Although this patient's maternal aunt has SLE, the girl's age makes SLE less likely. Also, a sharply demarcated erythema of the lower body is not a feature of SLE and suggests another etiology of this girl's symptoms.
Image Description:

An erythematous macular rash is visible over the nasal bridge, right cheek (malar eminence), and the right brow. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold.

This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. This rash is also referred to as a “butterfly rash” because it typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically and resembles the wings of a butterfly.

E) INCORRECT:

Ulcers of the oral mucosa with erythematous skin lesions can be seen in Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which can be triggered by certain medications (e.g., antiepileptics, sulfonamides) or infections (e.g., CMV, herpes). The recent skin infection and the antibiotics put this girl at risk for SJS. However, the rash characteristic of SJS is diffuse and involves the entire body without well-demarcated borders.
Image Description:

Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.
questions.hint: The distribution of injuries in this 3-year-old child should raise concern for child abuse.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 3-day history of nonbloody vomiting and poor feeding. He transitioned to pureed vegetables 10 days ago. Over the past 2 weeks, he has become increasingly irritable and within the past day has taken more daytime naps and appears much less responsive and interactive. His mother denies any history of fever or trauma at home. He has not received any vaccinations as his parents believe he is already healthy and does not need them. He spends most of the day with a babysitter while both parents are at work. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Auscultation of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The anterior fontanelle is tense and bulging. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral retinal hemorrhage. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows healing fractures of the 2nd and 3rd right ribs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tumors of the posterior fossa (e.g., juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma) are the most common pediatric primary brain tumors. A mass in the posterior fossa could gradually lead to altered mental status and could also increase intracranial pressure in a 7-month-old child to the extent that the anterior fontanelle would be tense and bulging. However, increased intracranial pressure would more likely be associated with papilledema on fundoscopic examination than retinal hemorrhages. In addition, this child's healing rib fractures should raise suspicion of a traumatic etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

The skeletal manifestations of vitamin D deficiency, rickets, can also be associated with pathological fractures of the ribs and other locations. However, this child has no other signs of bony deformities or fractures, and pathological fracture at an isolated location is less common in vitamin D deficiency. In addition, vitamin D deficiency is not associated with this patient's other findings of retinal hemorrhage, bulging anterior fontanelle, and altered mental status.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial meningitis could lead to altered mental status, which might manifest in the irritability and lethargy seen in this child. Before the anterior fontanelle closes (at 18–24 months of age), increased intracranial pressure (e.g., due to meningitis) can cause it to bulge. Children who are septic from meningitis may also rarely present with retinal hemorrhages. However, bacterial meningitis typically presents more acutely, in a matter of hours or days. Additionally, this child is afebrile and has a normal white blood cell count, both of which are unexpected findings in children with meningitis, particularly in meningitis due to bacterial pathogens.

D) INCORRECT:

An epidural hematoma could also lead to irritability, lethargy, signs of increased intracranial pressure, including a bulging anterior fontanelle, and retinal hemorrhage in rare cases. However, retinal hemorrhages are less frequently associated with epidural hemorrhage than other etiologies. Additionally, an epidural hematoma would likely present more acutely and with other physical examination findings, such as a visible hematoma or swelling in the area of head trauma, which this patient does not have. While this diagnosis cannot be excluded completely, a different option is more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is commonly seen in children with shaken baby syndrome (SBS). In such cases, DAI is most likely caused by rotational acceleration-deceleration forces inflicted by violent shaking of the infant and by secondary hypoxia (e.g., due to transient apnea). Long-term deficits resulting from SBS include sight, hearing, and speech impairment. SBS has an extremely high mortality rate, with approx. 25% of affected children dying as a result of sustained injuries. Cranial CT scan in patients with SBS often shows additional brain injuries such as chronic subdural hematoma (which would explain this patient's subacute presentation over 2 weeks), subarachnoid bleeding, and/or diffuse punctate parenchymal hemorrhages.

F) INCORRECT:

Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is caused by defective synthesis of type I collagen. Patients with this disorder are prone to pathologic fractures and may present with rib fractures. Skull fractures and associated intracranial bleeding are more common in children with OI and could cause altered mental status in the absence of a history of significant trauma. However, patients with OI often have blue sclera, hearing loss, and joint laxity, which are not present in this patient. Additionally, while OI is often hard to differentiate from child abuse, the low prevalence of OI makes child abuse more likely in the general population.

G) INCORRECT:

Many rodenticides contain long-acting anticoagulants, such as super warfarin. Ingestion of these rodenticides can lead to coagulopathy and pathological bleeding, usually beginning about 24 hours after ingestion. This coagulopathy could cause both retinal hemorrhages and intracranial bleeding leading to altered mental status, as seen in this patient. However, coagulopathy would likely also manifest in other locations, causing gastrointestinal bleeding, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and hematuria. This patient does not have any other signs of pathological bleeding, nor would this etiology explain this patient's associated rib fractures.
questions.hint: Retinal hemorrhage and associated rib fractures in a 7-month-old infant should raise concern for child abuse.

questions.text: A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 4-day history of vomiting, poor feeding, and more frequent napping. She appears lethargic. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulging, tense anterior fontanelle. Fundoscopic exam shows bilateral retinal hemorrhage. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 8,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows healing fractures of the 4th and 5th left ribs. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malnutrition can cause vitamin D deficiency, leading to rickets, which can cause pathological fractures of the ribs and other locations. However, this child has no other signs of bony deformities or fractures, and pathological fracture at an isolated location is less common in vitamin D deficiency. In addition, vitamin D deficiency is not associated with this patient's other findings of retinal hemorrhage, bulging anterior fontanelle, and lethargy.

Vitamin K deficiency, another possible result of malnutrition, causes aberrations in the coagulation cascade that may lead to retinal hemorrhages and intracranial bleeding, resulting in altered mental status. However, this patient does not have any of the other signs of vitamin K deficiency, such as ecchymoses, hemarthroses, hematomas, or hemorrhage from other sites.

B) INCORRECT:

Many rodenticides contain long-acting anticoagulants, such as “super warfarin”. Ingestion of these rodenticides can lead to coagulopathy and pathological bleeding, usually beginning about 24 hours after ingestion. This coagulopathy could cause both retinal hemorrhages and intracranial bleeding leading to altered mental status, as seen in this patient. However, coagulopathy would likely also manifest in other locations, causing gastrointestinal bleeding, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and hematuria. This patient does not have any other signs of pathological bleeding, nor would this etiology explain this patient's associated rib fractures.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's signs and symptoms are most consistent with shaken baby syndrome, in which rotational and shearing forces lead to injury of the bridging veins and consequent subdural hematoma. Infants have weak neck support, so shaking them can lead to respiratory problems and apnea, resulting in hypoxia and brain ischemia and edema. Ultimately, shaken baby syndrome leads to diffuse axonal damage, manifesting with massive neurological deficits such as impaired sight, hearing, and speech. The syndrome has an extremely high mortality rate (25%). Cranial CT scan of affected children often shows further injuries to the head, such as chronic subdural hematoma, subarachnoid bleeding, and diffuse punctate parenchymal hemorrhages.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is an inherited connective tissue disorder caused by defective synthesis of type I collagen. Patients with this disorder are prone to pathologic fractures and may present with rib fractures. Skull fractures and associated intracranial bleeding are more common in children with OI and could cause altered mental status in the absence of a history of significant trauma. However, patients with OI often have blue sclera, hearing loss, and joint laxity, which are not present in this patient. Additionally, while OI is often hard to differentiate from child abuse, the low prevalence of OI makes child abuse more likely in the general population.
Image Description:

The sclerae show a distinct blue-grey tint.

E) INCORRECT:

Germinal matrix hemorrhage can present with lethargy and a bulging anterior fontanelle, but it is most common in preterm infants and usually occurs within 5 days of birth. In addition, healing rib fractures and bilateral retinal hemorrhages would not be expected and should raise suspicion for a traumatic etiology.

F) INCORRECT:

Bacterial meningitis could lead to altered mental status, which might manifest in the irritability and lethargy seen in this child. Before the anterior fontanelle closes (between 18–24 months of age), increased intracranial pressure (e.g., due to meningitis) can cause it to bulge. Children who are septic from meningitis may also rarely present with retinal hemorrhages. However, bacterial meningitis typically presents more acutely, in a matter of hours or days. Additionally, this child is afebrile and has a normal white blood cell count, both of which are unexpected findings in children with meningitis, particularly in meningitis due to bacterial pathogens.
Image Description:

Macroscopic preparation of the cerebrum with a view of the arachnoid mater and the cortex

There is fibrinous purulent tissue, especially on the right and left side of the preparation site. The arachnoid mater appears milky yellow, especially along the major veins, which is due to the presence of purulent exudate in the subarachnoid space. These pathological changes of the meninges indicate acute bacterial meningitis, which, in the present case, is caused by pneumococci as a complication of lobar pneumonia.

G) INCORRECT:

An epidural hematoma could also lead to irritability, lethargy, signs of increased intracranial pressure, including a bulging anterior fontanelle, and retinal hemorrhage in rare cases. However, retinal hemorrhages are less frequently associated with epidural hemorrhage than other etiologies. Additionally, an epidural hematoma would likely present more acutely and with other physical exam findings, such as a visible hematoma or swelling in the area of head trauma, which this patient does not exhibit. While this diagnosis cannot be excluded completely, a different option is more likely.

Child abuse frequently leads to a subdural hematoma caused by rupture of the bridging veins (e.g., due to violent shaking of a child).
Image Description:

Most epidural hematomas (EDH) are caused by a rupture/tear of the middle meningeal artery secondary to a traumatic head injury, typically associated with a skull fracture. The resulting hemorrhage separates the dura mater from the inner aspect of the calvarium and accumulates within the epidural space. As the dura mater is tightly adherent at the skull suture lines, an EDH does not extend beyond the sutures. An EDH would be seen on neuroimaging as a biconvex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the suture lines.
questions.hint: Child Protective Services should be alerted of this case.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a painful rash on her hands and lower arms. According to the mother, she developed blisters and redness on her arms 2 days ago. Both parents claim there is no recent history of fever, itching, or trauma. Physical examination shows erythema and multiple fluid-filled bullae on the hands and arms up to the elbows with intermittent stripes of normal skin seen on the palmar aspect of the hand. The lesions are symmetrical in distribution and are sharply delineated. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?

choices.text: Schedule a follow-up examination for further evaluation
Ask both parents to leave the examination room to perform a forensic interview of the child
Obtain a biopsy specimen of the skin lesions for histopathological examination

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scheduling a follow-up examination is not indicated at this time. Instead, ensuring the child's safety is the most appropriate next step in management and should, therefore, take precedence.

B) CORRECT:

Physicians must notify Child Protective Services (CPS) immediately in cases of suspected child maltreatment. Findings suggestive of child maltreatment include signs of physical abuse, such as bruising, multiple fractures at different stages of healing, and scald burns. The presence of symmetrical sharply demarcated bullous lesions on this child's arms is highly suggestive of scald burns as a result of deliberate immersion in hot liquid. Accidental burns, such as spill burns resulting from hot liquid being spilled from a height, most often affect the head and neck in an asymmetrical pattern, unlike the symmetrical pattern seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Although conducting a forensic interview to obtain further evidence may become necessary in the future, ensuring the child's safety is the most appropriate next step in management and should, therefore, take precedence. While physicians should perform a basic initial interview with verbal children, a forensic interview with a 2-year-old girl should be performed by professionals who have been trained in the field of child maltreatment.

D) INCORRECT:

The child's skin findings most likely resulted from trauma caused by immersion of her arms in hot liquid. However, both parents deny a recent history of trauma, which should raise suspicion that the patient's history was fabricated by her parents. At this point, it is unlikely that talking to both parents individually will bring clarification. Moreover, confronting the parents with doubts about the truthfulness of their statements could lead to them avoiding further physician contact and subsequently place the child at risk of further injury and maltreatment.

E) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis of immersion burns can be made clinically and does not require histopathological examination of the affected skin. Instead, ensuring the patient's safety is the most appropriate next step in management.
questions.hint: Symmetrical, sharply demarcated lesions in a zebra-like pattern (intermittent stripes of normal skin with sparing of the flexion lines) are highly suggestive of immersion burns. Since both parents deny a recent history of trauma, the suspicion of child maltreatment is warranted.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of bed-wetting during the past 3 weeks. The mother is concerned because she has received phone calls from the school that her daughter has been acting out in class and making inappropriate jokes. Physical examination shows a thin female body habitus with no axillary or pubic hair. A few pink, fleshy papules measuring 3–5 mm in size are present on the vulva. There is no vulvar erythema or discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Reassure the mother and follow up with the patient
Interview the patient and mother separately
Recommend scheduled voiding and fluid restriction at night
Perform a urine dipstick test and measure serum glucose

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassuring the mother and following up with the patient is indicated in primary enuresis (the patient never achieved continence) up to 5 years of age whereas this patient has new-onset secondary enuresis (the patient previously achieved continence) at 9 years of age, which requires further workup. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.

B) CORRECT:

This child shows signs of sexual abuse, for which a well-documented patient interview is often the most important piece of evidence. In over 90% of cases, the perpetrator is an individual known to the child or their family. Therefore, it is important to interview the child separately from the parent to allow for a neutral and honest conversation. Furthermore, girls aged 9–12 years are at increased risk for sexual abuse. Behavioral changes that should raise concern for sexual abuse include sexually acting-out, sexual remarks that are inconsistent with age, problems at school, aggression, regression (e.g., nocturnal enuresis), eating or sleep disturbances, and depression. Medical conditions that should raise concern for sexual abuse include sexually transmitted infections (e.g., condylomata acuminata), pregnancies, recurrent urinary tract infections, and anogenital or oral trauma.

The threshold for investigating any suspected case of child abuse should be very low. The patient interview is followed by a careful physical examination and screening for STIs. Subsequently, the physician must notify Child Protective Services to protect the safety of the child and to ensure further investigation (including a forensic interview).

C) INCORRECT:

Scheduled voiding and fluid restriction at night are indicated as first-line therapy for nocturnal enuresis that is not caused by another medical condition in children older than 5 years of age. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.

D) INCORRECT:

Hospital social work services support patients and their families to cope with difficult situations, including suspected child maltreatment. While involving social workers may be warranted at a later point, another step in management is more urgently indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Performing a urine dipstick test and measuring serum glucose is indicated for ruling out type 1 diabetes. Secondary enuresis and nocturia, both of which are seen here, may occur in children with type 1 diabetes. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before she is assessed for type 1 diabetes.

F) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin therapy is indicated as second-line therapy for nocturnal enuresis that is not caused by another medical condition in children older than 5 years of age. This patient's additional behavioral changes and physical findings, however, raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.
questions.hint: This 9-year-old girl has new-onset nocturnal enuresis, behavioral changes, and features suggestive of condylomata acuminata.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a generalized seizure 3 hours ago. The episode lasted for 1 minute and was followed by nonbloody vomiting. The mother reports that the seizure started after the boy fell down the stairs while crawling around the house. He has also become increasingly irritable and refused to feed for the past few days. She says there have not been other episodes of seizure or history of trauma. The boy's immunizations are up-to-date. He appears lethargic. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. He has a pediatric Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 13. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There are multiple purple and yellow skin discolorations around his chest and back at the level of the 6th rib bilaterally. Results of initial laboratory studies are pending. CT scan of the head shows a thin, extraparenchymal, crescent-shaped, heterogeneous lesion that crosses the cranial sutures on the anterolateral aspect of the left hemisphere. In addition to intensive care and neurosurgical consultation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform genetic testing for bleeding disorders
Arrange for a meeting with both parents

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's bruises and SDH may be caused by a bleeding disorder. His platelet count and coagulation parameters (PT/INR, PTT) should be measured as a part of the initial workup to rule out bleeding disorders and in preparation for potential surgery. However, genetic testing for a bleeding disorder is not required unless the results of the initial workup suggest a bleeding disorder. This patient's initial laboratory workup is pending.

B) CORRECT:

In SBS, nonfebrile seizures, vomiting, irritability, and poor feeding can be the result of increased intracranial pressure due to the SDH (if the anterior fontanelle is closed) or due to diffuse axonal injury (which might not be evident on CT scan). Children below 2 years of age are prone to developing traumatic brain injury if they are shaken violently because they have a relatively large head, poor neck tone, increased water content of the brain, and flat skull base (which permits the brain to move easily). After stabilizing the patient, a skeletal survey and fundoscopy should be performed in all cases of suspected child abuse in order to evaluate for signs that cannot be detected on physical examination. Findings that support physical child abuse include multiple fractures at different stages of healing, metaphyseal and epiphyseal corner fractures, posterior rib fractures, spiral diaphyseal fractures of long bones (e.g., humerus), retinal hemorrhage, and vitreous hemorrhage. Suspected child abuse warrants an immediate notification of Child Protective Services.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical and imaging findings suggest abusive head trauma rather than a fall down the stairs as stated by the mother. At this point, it is highly unlikely that talking to both parents will help clarify the circumstances of the incident. Moreover, confronting the parents with doubts about the truthfulness of their statements could make them avoid further contact with the physician and thereby delay further evaluation and treatment for the boy.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has an SDH, which is a contraindication for lumbar puncture.

E) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography (EEG) is used to diagnose epileptic disorders and to risk-stratify patients with epileptic disorders for future seizures. In a child with a seizure, an EEG is performed after febrile seizures, CNS infections, and toxic, metabolic, and structural causes for a seizure have been ruled out by the initial workup (e.g., serum electrolytes and glucose, neuroimaging). This patient's initial workup reveals SDH, which is a structural cause of seizures. An EEG is therefore not required.
questions.hint: An extraparenchymal, crescent-shaped lesion that crosses the cranial sutures is consistent with a subdural hematoma (SDH), which is typically caused by tears in bridging veins due to sudden acceleration and/or deceleration. Without a plausible history, SDH in conjunction with bruises (purple and yellow skin discoloration) around the thorax at the level of the same rib (indicating a firm grip at this region) should raise concerns for shaken baby syndrome (SBS), a form of physical child abuse.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought in by his mother for evaluation of lesions around the anus that she noticed when he stepped out of the bathtub yesterday. The lesions are asymptomatic, and neither the boy nor his mother knows how long they have been there. The boy has not had rectal bleeding, itching, pain, fevers, or other associated symptoms.
On examination, there is a cluster of 2- to 6-mm flesh-colored papules in the perianal region.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Perform a Scotch tape test, and examine the findings under a microscope
Interview the mother to evaluate for possible sexual abuse
Prescribe imiquimod cream to be used until the lesions resolve
Reassure the patient and his mother that the lesions will resolve, but arrange for follow-up in 6 months
Prescribe a course of oral terbinafine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Scotch tape test is used to diagnose enterobiasis (pinworm infection). Tape is placed on the anus to collect eggs or worms that may then be viewed with a microscope. Enterobiasis usually manifests with pruritus and/or pain and erythema, not with painless flesh-colored papules.

B) CORRECT:

Painless, flesh-colored perianal papules are suggestive of condylomata acuminata (anogenital warts), which are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). The most common source of HPV transmission in children <2 years of age is through vertical contact from the mother during delivery. Delayed appearance of the infection after vertical transmission is possible and common, as is autoinoculation from other sites. However, transmission from sexual contact must be considered, especially in children >2 years of age, where approximately 20% of cases may involve inappropriate sexual contact.

Many anogenital warts resolve spontaneously in 6 to 12 months. However, it is not appropriate to merely provide reassurance without first assessing for concern about sexual abuse, ideally through conversation with a parent or guardian. If that individual raises concern, then consultation with a hospital social worker, a child protection program, or a regional children’s advocacy center may be indicated to discuss the most appropriate next steps in terms of interviewing the child and determining whether a report to child protective services is warranted.

Key learning point: The presence of condylomata acuminata in a prepubertal child should prompt evaluation for possible sexual abuse.

C) INCORRECT:

Imiquimod cream can be used to treat anogenital warts, but it is recommended only for children ≥12 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Many anogenital warts resolve spontaneously in 6 to 12 months. However, it is not appropriate to merely provide reassurance without first assessing for concern about sexual abuse, ideally through conversation with a parent or guardian.

E) INCORRECT:

Terbinafine is an antifungal medicine that can be used to treat tinea corporis, which usually appears as erythematous, scaly plaques. The diagnosis can be confirmed by fungal culture or potassium hydroxide (KOH) examination of skin scrapings. The perianal area is a very unlikely site for a fungal infection, and the clinical presentation in this case is not consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old girl is brought in by her mother for a 2-day history of fever, congestion, and wheezing. She was born at 35 weeks’ gestation and has eczema but is otherwise healthy. Her current medication includes triamcinolone cream as needed. She is formula-fed and eats solids. Her family history is unremarkable. Her mother reports that the girl rolled off the couch last week while sleeping but does not think she “hurt anything.”
The girl cries throughout the physical examination and seems to be generally tender over her anterior chest.
A chest radiograph is obtained and demonstrates posterior rib fractures (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by fragile bones. Osteopenia is typically seen on imaging as is bowing of the long bones in the lower extremities and wormian bones within the skull. The physical examination often reveals blue sclera (also a common finding in newborns) and discolored, grayish teeth. People with OI can also exhibit short stature, joint laxity, and hearing loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D-deficiency rickets is unlikely to cause posterior rib fractures and is unlikely in a healthy child who is formula-fed, as formula is fortified with vitamin D.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis, the most common iatrogenic cause of secondary osteoporosis, should be considered in patients taking oral or inhaled glucocorticoids. However, the condition should not be caused by intermittent topical application of a low-potency glucocorticoid and should not lead to posterior rib fractures.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's chest radiograph shows multiple healing rib fractures (right posterior 6th–9th, left lateral 6th–9th, and left posterior 6th–8th). Rib fractures, especially posterior rib fractures, have a high specificity for abuse. Thus, the most likely diagnosis in this child is inflicted injury.

Key learning point: Posterior rib fractures in a healthy infant are most likely to be a result of inflicted injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteopenia of prematurity can increase fracture risk in premature infants, but the fractures do not typically affect the posterior ribs.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents for follow-up of his previously diagnosed attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder. His mother states that he is “bouncing off the walls” and has been difficult to control. He is athletic, plays soccer, and loves to ride his bike, but he often falls, scraping his knees and elbows. His mother feels he needs an increase in his dose of methylphenidate because of his hyperactivity at home.
His height and weight are at the 75th and 25th percentiles, respectively. He has several scattered red and blue bruises along both shins, a 3-cm healed laceration on his right elbow, abrasions to both knees and his left forearm, and a 2-cm yellow bruise on his lateral left forehead. There is a red mark on his right thigh (figure).
Which one of the following examination findings is most concerning for physical abuse?

choices.text: The presence of a 2-cm bruise on the lateral forehead
The finding that his height and weight are at the 75th and 25th percentiles, respectively
The large number of bruises on his body
The location and pattern of the mark on his right thigh
The different ages of his many bruises

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A 2-cm bruise on the lateral forehead does not by itself raise concern for abuse because a bruise of this size and location would be a common accidental injury.

B) INCORRECT:

The discrepancy between the boy’s height and weight is not necessarily concerning and may reflect a recent growth spurt.

C) INCORRECT:

The number of bruises on the boy's body is not by itself concerning for physical abuse, given that all the skin findings (excluding the loop mark) are of a size and location that could be compatible with accidental mechanisms, given this child's developmental capabilities and activities.

D) CORRECT:

Observing patterns of bruises and scars is important to distinguish accidental injury from physical abuse. The image of the mark on this patient's right thigh shows a loop mark (curvilinear bruise with central sparing), which is consistent with an inflicted injury from a cord or other flexible, thin object. The location of this mark is also concerning for abuse, as the upper thigh is a very uncommon location for accidental bruising in children.

Key learning point: When evaluating bruises on children, a curvilinear pattern with central sparing is concerning for nonaccidental trauma (such as from a belt or cord injury).

E) INCORRECT:

Although the bruises noted are different colors, it is not possible to accurately date or age bruises by physical examination. Furthermore, in a child who's active, one could expect to see accidental injuries over different time periods.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 18-month-old girl has not been moving her left arm for the past day. Her mother cannot recall any specific preceding trauma but states that the girl began walking 3 months ago and still “falls down a lot.”
There is swelling of the left upper arm and pain with passive motion.
Radiography reveals a spiral fracture of the left humerus.
What is the best next step in evaluation of this child’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe vitamin D deficiency (when it results in osteomalacia) can lead to overt or occult fractures among children who are not the victims of physical abuse. Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a rare genetic bone disorder that is inherited through an autosomal dominant pattern, although sporadic mutations can occur. The most common form of OI is type 1, which accounts for approximately 80% of cases. Patients with OI or severe osteomalacia typically present with other findings on physical and radiological examinations by 18 months of age. Undertaking an evaluation for bone disorders such as these may be appropriate after taking a complete history and performing a detailed physical examination; however, testing for these conditions is not the most appropriate first step for a child who has been newly diagnosed with a seemingly pathologic fracture.

Furthermore, one should keep in mind that children with underlying medical disorders including bone disorders can also be victims of abuse and should be evaluated appropriately for that despite the presence of a possible alternative diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe vitamin D deficiency (when it results in osteomalacia) can lead to overt or occult fractures among children who are not the victims of physical abuse. Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a rare genetic bone disorder that is inherited through an autosomal dominant pattern, although sporadic mutations can occur. The most common form of OI is type 1, which accounts for approximately 80% of cases. Patients with OI or severe osteomalacia typically present with other findings on physical and radiological examinations by 18 months of age. Undertaking an evaluation for bone disorders such as these may be appropriate after taking a complete history and performing a detailed physical examination; however, testing for these conditions is not the most appropriate first step for a child who has been newly diagnosed with a seemingly pathologic fracture.

Furthermore, one should keep in mind that children with underlying medical disorders including bone disorders can also be victims of abuse and should be evaluated appropriately for that despite the presence of a possible alternative diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

An unexplained spiral humeral fracture in this child is concerning for physical abuse. Accidental spiral humeral shaft fractures are not common in young children. The mechanism of injury results from grabbing the upper arm and twisting.

When a child younger than 2 years of age is a suspected victim of physical abuse, the next step in evaluation is a skeletal survey to look for additional occult fractures, which may indicate prior injury or abuse. The skeletal survey should be repeated 2 weeks later to assess healing and appearance of nondisplaced fractures that were not previously identified. When abdominal trauma is being considered, appropriate testing can include liver function tests as well as measurement of amylase and lipase levels. When head trauma is considered, CT of the head is appropriate.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate for occult fractures in a child younger than 2 years of age who is a suspected victim of physical abuse is a skeletal survey.

D) INCORRECT:

Bone scans can be useful in the evaluation of fractures related to physical abuse, but they often require sedation in infants and young children and are not the best next step in evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone scans can be useful in the evaluation of fractures related to physical abuse, but they often require sedation in infants and young children and are not the best next step in evaluation.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of postprandial vomiting. Her father reports that she has diminished oral intake and increased sleepiness, but he reports observing no other symptoms.
On examination, the child is fussy but easily consoled. There is a 3-cm ecchymosis on her right forehead. She has a soft, nondistended belly with active bowel sounds.
An abdominal radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this child?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An upper gastrointestinal series is not an optimal choice to assess for trauma.

B) CORRECT:

This child’s abdominal radiograph reveals multiple healing rib fractures (left posterolateral 7th, 8th, and 9th; right posterior 7th, 8th, and 9th at the costovertebral junctions). The presence of such fractures in a child with lethargy, vomiting, and facial bruising is concerning for nonaccidental head trauma.

For a child with lethargy and vomiting, one needs to urgently rule out any intracranial trauma that would warrant surgical intervention. Abusive head trauma is the most common cause of death due to physical abuse. It is also the most common cause of traumatic death for children younger than one year of age. The skeletal injuries that frequently co-occur with head injury are long-bone, metaphyseal, and rib fractures. The most sensitive and specific test to diagnose abusive head trauma is CT of the head.

Abusive abdominal trauma is the second most common cause of death due to physical abuse. If there is concern for abdominal trauma, an abdominal CT is the more appropriate diagnostic study. Children with intra-abdominal injuries may lack abdominal bruising. They will often present with symptoms such as abdominal tenderness and distention; however, they may occasionally present asymptomatically. In those cases, elevated transaminase and lipase levels may alert the clinician to order an abdominal CT to rule out intra-abdominal trauma.

Key learning point: The test that is most likely to uncover the cause of vomiting, lethargy, and facial bruising is CT of the head.

C) INCORRECT:

Biochemical evaluation is appropriate for children with suspected metabolic or primary gastrointestinal disorders, but it is not the first-line evaluation for a child whose features are more consistent with physical abuse. Although pancreatic enzymes and serum electrolytes are likely to be measured as part of the workup for nonaccidental trauma, obtaining them is not the most important first step in evaluating this child with acutely altered mental status.

D) INCORRECT:

Ethanol intoxication can result in vomiting and lethargy in children. However, at 8 months old, this patient is developmentally unable to self-administer alcohol-containing liquids. Ethanol administration in this case would therefore have to be either intentional (as a form of child abuse) or neglectful. Given the signs of lethargy, vomiting, and facial bruising, along with the finding of healing rib fractures, this patient’s presentation is much more likely to be related to abusive head trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Biochemical evaluation is appropriate for children with suspected metabolic or primary gastrointestinal disorders, but it is not the first-line evaluation for a child whose features are more consistent with physical abuse. Although pancreatic enzymes and serum electrolytes are likely to be measured as part of the workup for nonaccidental trauma, obtaining them is not the most important first step in evaluating this child with acutely altered mental status.

questions.text:
The mother of a 6-month-old boy reports that he is not bearing weight on his right leg. He has been fussier than usual for the past day and refuses to put his right foot down when held in a standing position. He was cared for by a new babysitter this week, and she did not report any trauma or illness in him. He has no significant medical or family history.
He exhibits some tenderness when the right leg is manipulated, but his examination is otherwise unremarkable.
A radiograph of the right leg is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely cause of this child’s leg pain?

choices.text: Injury from pulling or twisting of the leg
Blunt force injury perpendicular to the bone
Injury from crawling on a hard floor
Injury from falling from a height of less than 1.5 meters
Injury from bouncing on an outstretched leg

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This child has classic metaphyseal lesions (CMLs) of the proximal and distal tibia. CMLs, also known as metaphyseal corner fractures or bucket-handle fractures, are among the most highly specific fractures associated with abuse. The following radiograph shows a curvilinear structure emanating from the proximal and distal metaphyses of the tibia, which takes the appearance of a bucket handle (arrows).

The mechanism required to produce CMLs is a torsional or shearing strain, as when the extremity is pulled or twisted. Providers are mandated by law to report suspected child abuse to the local child protective services or law enforcement agency.

Key learning point: The mechanism required to produce classic metaphyseal lesions is a torsional or shearing strain.

B) INCORRECT:

Blunt force perpendicular to the bone is associated with oblique or transverse fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

Crawling on a hard floor or falling from a short height is unlikely to produce an extremity fracture in an otherwise healthy child.

D) INCORRECT:

Crawling on a hard floor or falling from a short height is unlikely to produce an extremity fracture in an otherwise healthy child.

E) INCORRECT:

Bouncing on an outstretched leg with significant force may cause a buckle fracture but is not associated with CMLs.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl who entered foster care 2 weeks ago because of suspected sexual abuse by her stepfather presents with a one-week history of dysuria and vaginal discharge. She had no previous medical problems and has not recently used antibiotics. She reports no itching, bubble baths, or wiping back to front.
Physical examination reveals a crescent-shaped hymen with an erythematous vaginal vault, copious thick green discharge, and no signs of trauma.
What is the most likely cause of this girl’s vaginal discharge?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Trichomonas vaginalis can be transmitted by sexual abuse, and the infection can result in vaginal discharge and irritation, it does not typically manifest with copious green vaginal discharge, as described in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Vulvovaginitis related to Candida albicans manifests with thick white vaginal discharge (not thick green discharge) and is unlikely in a healthy school-age child who has no recent history of antibiotic use.

C) INCORRECT:

Pinworms can travel from the anus into the vaginal vault, where they cause intense pruritus but not discharge. This patient does not report any itching.

D) INCORRECT:

Vulvovaginitis related to poor hygiene is common in prepubertal girls and is often related to improper wiping (from back to front) or bubble baths causing contact dermatitis. However, it is less likely than N. gonorrhoeae infection to cause the copious green discharge noted here.

E) CORRECT:

This patient likely has vulvovaginitis related to Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, given the presence of thick green vaginal discharge and dysuria. Sexually transmitted infections occur infrequently in prepubertal children who have been sexually abused (approximately 5% of cases). However, prepubertal girls who have a history of sexual abuse and vaginal discharge are more likely to have a sexually transmitted infection. Most children who have been sexually abused have normal anogenital examinations, so a normal examination with a crescent-shaped hymen does not rule out sexual abuse. Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae (outside of the newborn period) carries a high association for sexual abuse.

Key learning point: Green vaginal discharge with associated dysuria in a prepubescent girl should prompt investigation for Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl with a mitochondrial disorder was admitted to the general pediatrics ward for vomiting. She is currently receiving total parenteral nutrition through a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line. She is scheduled for PICC-line removal and transition to nasogastric tube feedings tomorrow in preparation for discharge home. Her mother has expressed concerns that she will not tolerate the transition.
Overnight, the girl develops a fever of 39.0°C. On examination, she has a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 92/52 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. She is given acetaminophen and two boluses of normal saline. Antibiotic treatment is initiated with vancomycin and ceftriaxone. During the next 36 hours, her blood pressure normalizes, and she defervesces.
Before the administration of antibiotics, blood cultures are drawn from the PICC line as well as peripherally. The blood culture from the PICC line is positive for Enterococcus and Escherichia coli. The peripheral cultures are negative
Review of the patient’s medical chart reveals that 2 months ago, she was hospitalized for intractable emesis and received an extensive evaluation that turned out to be negative; during that hospitalization, she had a central line placed for total parenteral nutrition and developed bacteremia with E. coli and Klebsiella. She also underwent an upper gastrointestinal study in the past year to evaluate vomiting, and the results were normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this child?

choices.text: Consult pediatric surgery for placement of a port
Confront the mother about concerns regarding intentional contamination of the central line
Transfer the patient to another hospital
Initiate a workup for immune deficiency
Consult a child-abuse specialist or child-protection team

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placement of a more-permanent line would subject this patient to further unnecessary harm and increase her risk for additional bacterial infections. The goal is to remove unnecessary lines as soon as possible.

B) INCORRECT:

Although further medical investigation may be necessary, evaluation for medical child abuse should begin with the aid of a specialist. Confronting the mother directly might put the child at risk for further, possibly greater, harm (including death).

C) INCORRECT:

Transfer to another hospital is unnecessary at this time and may delay appropriate diagnosis and treatment. If the admitting hospital itself does not have a child-protection team or specialist available, then consultation with an outside child-abuse specialist is warranted.

D) INCORRECT:

Although recurrent bacteremia can be an indication of an underlying immunodeficiency, in this case, polymicrobial sepsis with bowel flora is more suggestive of central-line contamination.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's history suggests medical child abuse, which is also known as factitious disorder imposed on another or factitious disorder by proxy (formerly referred to as Munchausen syndrome by proxy). Medical child abuse involves the exaggeration, falsification, or induction of illness in a child by a caregiver, resulting in the child receiving unnecessary and harmful (or potentially harmful) medical care. Having an underlying medical illness does not preclude a diagnosis of medical child abuse, as up to 30% of affected children have a separate medical condition from the one being fabricated or induced by the caregiver.

Diagnosis of medical child abuse is difficult and requires a high index of suspicion. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends considering the following questions when evaluating a patient for suspected medical child abuse:

• Are the history, signs, and symptoms of disease credible?
• Is the child receiving unnecessary and harmful (or potentially harmful) medical care?
• If so, who is instigating the evaluation and treatment?

In this case, the child has had two recent episodes of polymicrobial sepsis with bowel flora. This suggests central-line contamination, which requires urgent consultation with a child-abuse specialist, typically through a child-protection team within the hospital setting. The specialist will be able to guide the team as to how best to protect the child immediately. Recommendations may include safety measures such as having one-to-one staffing with an experienced nurse or care partner staying at the bedside with close monitoring — or perhaps transferring the patient to the hospital’s pediatric intensive care unit for monitoring. The specialist can assist in reviewing records and reporting to child-protective services. Seeking out additional records from outside health care providers and institutions is important because victims of medical child abuse have often been evaluated at many locations. Consultation with psychiatry and legal professionals is also recommended.

Key learning point: Concern for medical child abuse requires consultation with a child-abuse specialist or child-protection team.

questions.text:
A 7-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department via ambulance after his mother had difficulty awakening him for a feed. The mother explains that the child has been with a babysitter during the day since she returned to work. The babysitter had mentioned to the mother that the child was vomiting more frequently and seemed fussy during the past 2 days.
The patient’s vital signs are stable, but he appears lethargic, hypotonic, and pale. He has a 1.5-cm ecchymosis on the left ear and a 5-cm x 4-cm cephalohematoma on the posterior parietal portion of the skull.
CT of the head is obtained (figure).
After airway stabilization and neurosurgery consultation, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoprecipitate may be considered in clinical scenarios where the patient has significant bleeding. It is most helpful in low fibrinogen states. If a congenital bleeding disorder such as hemophilia A or hemophilia B is suspected, giving the patient a dose of the missing factor is more beneficial. A congenital bleeding disorder in the absence of trauma would not cause a skull fracture.

B) INCORRECT:

Retinal hemorrhages can be one of the earliest signs of intracranial injury in NAT. This patient is at risk for retinal hemorrhages, and an ophthalmologic consultation early in the hospital course is critical, but it is not the most appropriate next step.

C) INCORRECT:

Although an infection involving the central nervous system may cause symptoms similar to this patient’s (typically fever, vomiting, and altered mental status), the CT scan in this case shows a skull fracture with an extra-axial hematoma, highly suggestive of NAT. A lumbar puncture would not add diagnostic value and could put the patient at greater risk given his current clinical instability.

D) CORRECT:

Nonaccidental trauma (NAT) should be considered when children present with unexplained or poorly explained injuries that are not consistent with their level of development or when there appears to be a delay in seeking care for concerning symptoms. Symptoms of abusive head trauma in infants can be nonspecific and may include poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, fussiness, hypotonia, and seizures. The presence of scalp swelling should raise concern for a possible skull fracture. The finding of the left-ear bruise on this nonmobile infant is a sentinel injury for abuse and should not be overlooked. Lack of recognition of NAT can result in severe morbidity or, possibly, death. Referral to child protective services (CPS) is a critical next step.

Radiologic evaluation of NAT includes the following components:

• CT of the brain (acutely) or MRI of the brain (if the patient is asymptomatic) to assess for intracranial injury
• Skeletal survey to assess for other fractures
• CT of the abdomen and pelvis if intra-abdominal organ damage is suspected

A skeletal survey is the best method to identify fractures in infants and children <2 years of age whose presentation is concerning for physical abuse. A complete skeletal survey entails multiple images of the entire body (approximately 20 images), which may reveal additional acute as well as healing fractures that may not have been part of a patient’s initial presenting complaint.

Nonradiologic evaluation of NAT should include a full physical examination with the child unclothed, a fundoscopic examination to assess for retinal hemorrhages, basic laboratory testing such as a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, coagulation studies in cases with bleeding, and hepatic and pancreatic enzyme levels to assess for intra-abdominal injury.

Stabilizing the patient is of utmost importance. Patients with depressed mental status require intubation for airway protection before imaging is conducted. Hypertension, bradycardia, and erratic breathing may suggest impending brainstem herniation. Consulting the neurosurgery team, administering hypertonic saline or mannitol, and elevating the head of the bed may reduce the likelihood of this complication.

The presence of a skull fracture and an extra-axial hematoma is highly concerning for abusive head trauma. Once the patient is stabilized, a member of the team should contact CPS to report their suspicion.

Key learning point: After acute stabilization and neurosurgery consultation, the most appropriate next step for an infant who presents to the emergency department with an unexplained skull fracture and extra-axial hematoma is notification of child protective services.

E) INCORRECT:

A skeletal survey is the best method to identify fractures in infants and children <2 years of age whose presentation is concerning for physical abuse. A complete skeletal survey entails multiple images of the entire body (approximately 20 images), which may reveal additional acute as well as healing fractures that may not have been part of a patient’s initial presenting complaint.

A single whole-body radiograph (“babygram”) is simply one anteroposterior view of an infant that includes the chest, abdomen, and extremities. It is an inadequate study and is not sensitive or specific enough to identify the bones in detail and rule out occult fractures.

questions.text: A hospitalized 11-year-old girl with a mitochondrial disease has a 12-hour history of high fever. She was admitted to the pediatrics ward because of a 1-week history of severe vomiting. Since her admission, she has received total parenteral nutrition through a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line in her left upper extremity. Yesterday, she was scheduled for PICC removal and transition to nasogastric tube feeding in preparation for discharge home. Her mother had expressed concerns that she would not tolerate the transition. She has had similar episodes of intractable vomiting in the past and underwent an inconclusive upper gastrointestinal study 6 months ago. She was also hospitalized two months ago for vomiting and received an extensive evaluation that turned out to be negative. During the last hospitalization, she had a central line placed and developed bacteremia with E. coli and Klebsiella. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 92/52 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Blood cultures are drawn from the PICC and a peripheral venipuncture, and treatment with acetaminophen, two boluses of normal saline, vancomycin, and ceftriaxone are initiated. The results of urinalysis, echocardiography, and CT scan of the chest and abdomen show no abnormalities. Three days after initiating treatment, the patient's blood pressure normalizes. Cultures from the PICC line grow Enterococcus and E. coli, and cultures from the peripheral venipuncture become positive for the same organisms 12 hours later with one-tenth the number of colony-forming units that grew in the PICC line cultures. A review of hospital records from the past month discloses that no other patients with intravascular catheters have developed bacteremia with these organisms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Consult pediatric surgery for placement of a implanted central venous port
Consult the hospital's child protection team
Consult pediatric surgery for placement of a gastrojejunostomy tube
Perform additional workup to detect an occult bowel perforation
Perform a workup for immune deficiency

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placement of a more-permanent line would subject this patient to further unnecessary harm and increase her risk for additional bacterial infections. The goal is to remove unnecessary lines as soon as possible.

B) CORRECT:

This child has had two recent CRBSIs with bowel flora. The PICC's upper extremity location and the patient's age make it unlikely that she accidentally soiled the PICC with fecal matter. Iatrogenic contamination of the PICC with bowel flora (e.g., due to inadequate hand hygiene, contamination of parenteral nutrition modules) is also unlikely to be the cause of this patient's CRBSI given the absence of CRBSIs due to bowel flora in other patients at the hospital. This patient's history suggests medical child abuse, also known as factitious disorder by proxy, which involves the exaggeration, falsification, or induction of illness in a child by a caregiver, resulting in the child receiving unnecessary medical care. Some commonly reported examples include contaminating medical equipment or samples, inducing vomiting or diarrhea, injecting poisons or infectious material into a venous line, and suffocating a child to induce apneic episodes. Diagnosis of medical child abuse requires a high level of suspicion. Red flags include an atypical illness course, infections by atypical organisms without a plausible explanation, and clinical deterioration that occurs just before discharge. Having an underlying medical illness does not rule out a diagnosis of medical child abuse, as up to 30% of affected children have a medical condition unrelated to the one being fabricated or induced by the caregiver.

It is necessary to urgently consult a child abuse specialist, typically through a child protection team within a hospital setting. Confronting the caregiver directly might put the child at risk for further, possibly greater, harm. The specialist will be able to guide the team on the best ways to immediately protect the child. Recommendations may include safety measures such as one-to-one staffing and close monitoring by an experienced provider staying at the bedside, or transferring the patient to the hospital’s pediatric intensive care unit to separate them from their caregiver. The specialist also can assist in reviewing records and reporting to child protective services. Seeking additional records from outside healthcare providers and institutions is important because victims of medical child abuse have often been evaluated at multiple locations. Consultation with psychiatry and legal professionals is also recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Enteral nutrition via percutaneous access (e.g., with a gastrojejunostomy tube) is only indicated if nutritional support is anticipated for approx. > 4 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Bowel flora is responsible for this patient's polymicrobial bloodstream infection (BSI) but the culture results indicate a primary BSI (with the PICC being the source of infection) rather than a secondary BSI (e.g., due to occult bowel perforation).

E) INCORRECT:

Although recurrent bacteremia can be due to an underlying immunodeficiency, in this case, central line contamination is the underlying cause of sepsis.
questions.hint: A catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI) is confirmed if the same organisms are grown from the catheter and venipuncture samples, and the differential time to positivity is > 120 minutes or the catheter culture has ≥ 3 times the number of colony-forming units as the venipuncture culture. CRBSIs are typically caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci, S. aureus, Pseudomonas, or Candida, not bowel flora like E. coli, Klebsiella, or Enterococcus.

Her mother cannot recall any specific preceding trauma but states that the girl began walking 3 months ago and still “falls down a lot.” There is swelling of the left upper arm and pain with passive motion.
