D) INCORRECT:

Bone scans can be useful in the evaluation of fractures related to physical abuse, but they often require sedation in infants and young children and are not the best next step in evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone scans can be useful in the evaluation of fractures related to physical abuse, but they often require sedation in infants and young children and are not the best next step in evaluation.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of bed-wetting during the past 3 weeks. The mother is concerned because she has received phone calls from the school that her daughter has been acting out in class and making inappropriate jokes. Physical examination shows a thin female body habitus with no axillary or pubic hair. A few pink, fleshy papules measuring 3–5 mm in size are present on the vulva. There is no vulvar erythema or discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Reassure the mother and follow up with the patient
Interview the patient and mother separately
Recommend scheduled voiding and fluid restriction at night
Perform a urine dipstick test and measure serum glucose

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassuring the mother and following up with the patient is indicated in primary enuresis (the patient never achieved continence) up to 5 years of age whereas this patient has new-onset secondary enuresis (the patient previously achieved continence) at 9 years of age, which requires further workup. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.

B) CORRECT:

This child shows signs of sexual abuse, for which a well-documented patient interview is often the most important piece of evidence. In over 90% of cases, the perpetrator is an individual known to the child or their family. Therefore, it is important to interview the child separately from the parent to allow for a neutral and honest conversation. Furthermore, girls aged 9–12 years are at increased risk for sexual abuse. Behavioral changes that should raise concern for sexual abuse include sexually acting-out, sexual remarks that are inconsistent with age, problems at school, aggression, regression (e.g., nocturnal enuresis), eating or sleep disturbances, and depression. Medical conditions that should raise concern for sexual abuse include sexually transmitted infections (e.g., condylomata acuminata), pregnancies, recurrent urinary tract infections, and anogenital or oral trauma.

The threshold for investigating any suspected case of child abuse should be very low. The patient interview is followed by a careful physical examination and screening for STIs. Subsequently, the physician must notify Child Protective Services to protect the safety of the child and to ensure further investigation (including a forensic interview).

C) INCORRECT:

Scheduled voiding and fluid restriction at night are indicated as first-line therapy for nocturnal enuresis that is not caused by another medical condition in children older than 5 years of age. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.

D) INCORRECT:

Performing a urine dipstick test and measuring serum glucose is indicated for ruling out type 1 diabetes. Secondary enuresis and nocturia, both of which are seen here, may occur in children with type 1 diabetes. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before she is assessed for type 1 diabetes.

E) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin therapy is indicated as second-line therapy for nocturnal enuresis that is not caused by another medical condition in children older than 5 years of age. This patient's additional behavioral changes and physical findings, however, raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.
questions.hint: This 9-year-old girl has new-onset nocturnal enuresis, behavioral changes, and features suggestive of condylomata acuminata.

questions.text: A 7-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department via ambulance after his mother had difficulty awakening him for a feed. The mother explains that the child has been with a babysitter during the day since she returned to work. The babysitter had mentioned to the mother that the child was vomiting more frequently and seemed fussy during the past 2 days. The patient’s vital signs are stable, but he appears lethargic, hypotonic, and pale. He has a 1.5-cm ecchymosis on the left ear and a 5-cm x 4-cm cephalohematoma on the posterior parietal portion of the skull. CT of the head is obtained (figure). After airway stabilization and neurosurgery consultation, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoprecipitate may be considered in clinical scenarios where the patient has significant bleeding. It is most helpful in low fibrinogen states. If a congenital bleeding disorder such as hemophilia A or hemophilia B is suspected, giving the patient a dose of the missing factor is more beneficial. A congenital bleeding disorder in the absence of trauma would not cause a skull fracture.

B) INCORRECT:

Retinal hemorrhages can be one of the earliest signs of intracranial injury in NAT. This patient is at risk for retinal hemorrhages, and an ophthalmologic consultation early in the hospital course is critical, but it is not the most appropriate next step.

C) INCORRECT:

Although an infection involving the central nervous system may cause symptoms similar to this patient’s (typically fever, vomiting, and altered mental status), the CT scan in this case shows a skull fracture with an extra-axial hematoma, highly suggestive of NAT. A lumbar puncture would not add diagnostic value and could put the patient at greater risk given his current clinical instability.

D) CORRECT:

Nonaccidental trauma (NAT) should be considered when children present with unexplained or poorly explained injuries that are not consistent with their level of development or when there appears to be a delay in seeking care for concerning symptoms. Symptoms of abusive head trauma in infants can be nonspecific and may include poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, fussiness, hypotonia, and seizures. The presence of scalp swelling should raise concern for a possible skull fracture. The finding of the left-ear bruise on this nonmobile infant is a sentinel injury for abuse and should not be overlooked. Lack of recognition of NAT can result in severe morbidity or, possibly, death. Referral to child protective services (CPS) is a critical next step.

Radiologic evaluation of NAT includes the following components:

• CT of the brain (acutely) or MRI of the brain (if the patient is asymptomatic) to assess for intracranial injury
• Skeletal survey to assess for other fractures
• CT of the abdomen and pelvis if intra-abdominal organ damage is suspected

A skeletal survey is the best method to identify fractures in infants and children <2 years of age whose presentation is concerning for physical abuse. A complete skeletal survey entails multiple images of the entire body (approximately 20 images), which may reveal additional acute as well as healing fractures that may not have been part of a patient’s initial presenting complaint.

Nonradiologic evaluation of NAT should include a full physical examination with the child unclothed, a fundoscopic examination to assess for retinal hemorrhages, basic laboratory testing such as a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, coagulation studies in cases with bleeding, and hepatic and pancreatic enzyme levels to assess for intra-abdominal injury.

Stabilizing the patient is of utmost importance. Patients with depressed mental status require intubation for airway protection before imaging is conducted. Hypertension, bradycardia, and erratic breathing may suggest impending brainstem herniation. Consulting the neurosurgery team, administering hypertonic saline or mannitol, and elevating the head of the bed may reduce the likelihood of this complication.

The presence of a skull fracture and an extra-axial hematoma is highly concerning for abusive head trauma. Once the patient is stabilized, a member of the team should contact CPS to report their suspicion.

Key learning point: After acute stabilization and neurosurgery consultation, the most appropriate next step for an infant who presents to the emergency department with an unexplained skull fracture and extra-axial hematoma is notification of child protective services.

E) INCORRECT:

A skeletal survey is the best method to identify fractures in infants and children <2 years of age whose presentation is concerning for physical abuse. A complete skeletal survey entails multiple images of the entire body (approximately 20 images), which may reveal additional acute as well as healing fractures that may not have been part of a patient’s initial presenting complaint.

A single whole-body radiograph (“babygram”) is simply one anteroposterior view of an infant that includes the chest, abdomen, and extremities. It is an inadequate study and is not sensitive or specific enough to identify the bones in detail and rule out occult fractures.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a day of excessive crying, vomiting, and irritability. Physical examination shows bruises in different stages of healing on his torso and arms. Fundoscopic exam reveals bilateral flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages. Head imaging demonstrates bilateral extra-axial fluid collections along the convexities. Chest radiographs show healing rib fractures. His vital signs are stable. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The severe injuries, including retinal hemorrhages and subdural collections, result from significant forces not typically seen in minor household accidents. Rib fractures in different stages of healing suggest repeated trauma, not a single accidental event.

B) CORRECT:

The findings of bruises in various stages of healing, healing rib fractures, bilateral flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, and extra-axial fluid collections are indicative of non-accidental head trauma, often seen in abusive head trauma. Violent shaking causes acceleration-deceleration forces, leading to tearing of bridging veins and subdural hematomas, as well as retinal hemorrhages. The presence of injuries at different stages of healing suggests repetitive trauma, a hallmark of child abuse.

Key learning point: The combination of subdural hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhage, and old fractures in an infant is highly suggestive of child abuse, specifically abusive head trauma or shaken baby syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemophilia typically presents with deep tissue hematomas and hemarthroses, not the pattern of injuries seen here. The presence of multiple bruises in different stages of healing and healing rib fractures suggests repetitive trauma. Retinal hemorrhages from acceleration-deceleration forces are not characteristic of hemophilia.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteogenesis imperfecta is associated with bone fragility and fractures but typically presents with blue sclerae and dentinogenesis imperfecta, which are not mentioned here. Retinal hemorrhages and subdural hematomas are not characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department after reportedly falling off a couch. He appears lethargic, and his anterior fontanelle is bulging on examination. Bruises of varying ages are noted on both arms, and an older-looking fracture is visible on X-ray. A head CT reveals a subdural hemorrhage, and funduscopic evaluation shows bilateral retinal hemorrhages. Vital signs remain stable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Consult an orthopedic surgeon for definitive management of the older fracture
Prescribe analgesics and discharge for outpatient follow-up

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of subdural hemorrhage, bilateral retinal hemorrhages, an older fracture, and bruises of varying ages strongly suggests non-accidental trauma, commonly associated with child abuse. These findings necessitate immediate reporting to child protective services to ensure the child's safety and initiate a comprehensive investigation. Recognizing these clinical and radiological signs is crucial for preventing further harm and guiding early intervention.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected child abuse, especially with clinical signs like subdural hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhages, and old fractures, it is crucial to involve child protection services to ensure the child's safety and prevent further harm.

B) INCORRECT:

While orthopedic follow-up may be needed for the older fracture, the immediate concern is the acute neurologic injury indicated by lethargy, bulging fontanelle, subdural hemorrhage, and retinal hemorrhages. These signs suggest abusive head trauma, requiring urgent neurocritical evaluation and protective interventions rather than prioritizing orthopedic consultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Prescribing analgesics and arranging outpatient follow-up is inappropriate given the significant intracranial pathology, including subdural hemorrhage and retinal hemorrhages, which are not typical of minor falls. The presence of multiple bruises and an older fracture suggests repeated injury, necessitating hospital admission and protective measures rather than simple symptomatic management.

D) INCORRECT:

Inherited bleeding disorders can cause increased bleeding but typically present with joint or muscle bleeding, not the pattern seen here. The combination of subdural hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhages, multiple bruises, and an old fracture suggests repetitive trauma rather than a bleeding diathesis. There is no mention of a family history of bleeding disorders, making this an unlikely cause.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic with complaints of persistent fatigue and poor growth. She is under the 5th percentile for height and weight. Her mother reports frequent missed meals due to financial difficulties. The child has missed multiple scheduled appointments over the past year. Physical examination shows patchy hair loss, brittle nails, and thin arms. Vital signs are stable. Laboratory tests are pending. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a detailed psychological assessment of the mother
Admit the child for inpatient nutritional support and close monitoring
Prescribe a high-calorie diet plan and reevaluate in one month

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The stem highlights socioeconomic challenges as the primary issue, not psychological concerns. The child's symptoms are consistent with nutritional deficiencies due to limited food intake. Addressing the child's nutritional status and well-being should be prioritized over investigating maternal psychological issues without supporting evidence.

B) INCORRECT:

Inpatient care is reserved for hemodynamically unstable children or those with acute malnutrition complications. This child is medically stable, with chronic undernutrition due to socioeconomic challenges. Outpatient management, including nutritional assessment and social services intervention, is appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

While a high-calorie diet might address undernutrition, it does not tackle the underlying issues of food insecurity and potential neglect. The child's situation involves broader social challenges, such as financial difficulties and missed appointments, which require a multidisciplinary approach to ensure safety and proper care.

D) CORRECT:

The child's presentation, including growth below the 5th percentile, signs of undernutrition such as patchy hair loss and brittle nails, and a history of missed appointments, suggests nutritional neglect. Despite financial difficulties, there is a legal and ethical obligation to report suspected neglect to child protective services. This action initiates a multidisciplinary evaluation to address the child's medical needs and the family's social challenges, ensuring the child's safety and well-being.

Key learning point: In cases where a child's health is being compromised by a caregiver's actions or neglect, it is appropriate to involve child protection services to ensure the child's welfare and safety.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought by her mother because of new-onset stool incontinence over the past two weeks. The mother also reports intermittent genital pain and spotting of blood on her daughter’s underwear, which she initially attributed to poor hygiene. On examination, there is bruising on the inner thighs and vulvar erythema with a small amount of dried blood at the introitus. The child appears anxious and avoids eye contact. Temperature is 37.2°C, heart rate is 95/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. An abdominal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Notify child protective services for suspected abuse
Obtain stool studies for parasitic infection
Scheduled follow-up with a pediatric gynecologist in 1–2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The presence of bruising on the inner thighs, vulvar erythema, and dried blood at the introitus in a prepubertal child, along with new-onset stool incontinence and reported genital pain, raises significant concern for non-accidental trauma. Behavioral cues such as anxiety and avoidance of eye contact further suggest potential sexual abuse. Healthcare providers must act in accordance with mandated reporting laws to ensure the child's protection, initiate a thorough multidisciplinary evaluation, and facilitate timely intervention.

Key learning point: In young children, the presence of unexplained vaginal bleeding, bruising, and behavioral changes such as stool incontinence should raise suspicion for sexual abuse.

B) INCORRECT:

While vulvar erythema might suggest a fungal infection, the presence of inner thigh bruising, blood spotting, stool incontinence, and the child's withdrawn behavior do not align with candidal vulvovaginitis. Candidal infections typically present with pruritus and a white discharge, not bleeding or trauma-related bruising.

C) INCORRECT:

Stool studies are considered for chronic diarrhea or malabsorption, not for the presented symptoms. New-onset stool incontinence, genital pain, blood spotting, and bruising suggest trauma rather than a parasitic infection. The child's anxious behavior further indicates possible abuse, not a gastrointestinal issue.

D) INCORRECT:

Referral to a pediatric gynecologist may be part of care, but the findings suggest sexual abuse, requiring immediate evaluation. Bruising, genital erythema with blood, and behavioral signs necessitate prompt forensic assessment and child protection services involvement to prevent evidence loss and ensure safety.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents with her mother for recurrent episodes of crying and refusal to attend school. On examination, she appears withdrawn and flinches when touched. There are bruises of varying ages on her forearms. Her vital signs are normal. The mother attributes the child’s behavior to academic stress. She remains present in the exam room. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure the mother that the child’s behavior is related to academic stress
Schedule a joint appointment to discuss the child’s issues with her mother present
Interview the child privately in a secure setting away from her mother
Order immediate imaging studies of her arms before further questioning

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The child's withdrawal, hypersensitivity to touch, and bruises of varying ages suggest physical trauma rather than stress. These findings, combined with the mother's attribution of behavior to academic pressure, warrant suspicion for abuse. Reassuring the mother without further investigation neglects the need to assess the child's safety and the etiology of the injuries.

B) INCORRECT:

Involving the caregiver in discussions when abuse is suspected may inhibit the child's disclosure of sensitive information. Conducting an interview with the child alone ensures a safe environment for sharing details without fear of repercussions. Best practices in suspected child maltreatment include establishing a secure, confidential setting for the child's interview.

C) CORRECT:

The child's withdrawn behavior, flinching at touch, and bruises of varying ages raise suspicion for abuse. Conducting a private interview in a secure setting away from caregivers is crucial to ensure the child feels safe to disclose sensitive information. This approach helps establish trust and minimizes the risk of intimidation by a potential abuser. Speaking with the child alone allows the clinician to gather a complete history and assess the situation accurately, which is essential for initiating protective and legal interventions.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected abuse, it is crucial to explore the patient's emotional state and underlying causes of distress in a safe and supportive environment, without the presence of potentially involved family members.

D) INCORRECT:

While imaging can document bone injuries in suspected abuse, it is crucial to first obtain a detailed history and conduct a confidential interview. Immediate imaging does not address the need to clarify the circumstances of the injuries or establish whether abuse is ongoing. A thorough psychosocial and protective assessment is warranted before ancillary tests.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-year-old girl in the emergency department who is brought in by her parents because of a painful rash on her hands and lower arms. Her mother reports that blisters and redness developed on her arms 2 days ago. Her parents state there has been no recent fever, itching, or trauma. On examination, there is erythema and multiple fluid-filled bullae on the hands and arms up to the elbows, with intermittent stripes of normal skin on the palmar aspect of the hand. The lesions are symmetrical and sharply demarcated. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial action?

choices.text: Obtain a biopsy specimen of the skin lesions for histopathological examination.
Notify the provincial child welfare agency.
Ask both parents to leave the examination room to perform a forensic interview of the child.
Schedule a follow-up examination for further evaluation.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The child's skin findings most likely resulted from trauma caused by immersion of her arms in hot liquid. However, both parents deny a recent history of trauma, which should raise suspicion that the patient's history was fabricated by her parents. At this point, it is unlikely that talking to both parents individually will bring clarification. Moreover, confronting the parents with doubts about the truthfulness of their statements could lead to them avoiding further physician contact and subsequently place the child at risk of further injury and maltreatment.

B) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis of immersion burns can be made clinically and does not require histopathological examination of the affected skin. Instead, ensuring the patient's safety is the most appropriate next step in management.

C) CORRECT:

Physicians must notify the appropriate provincial child welfare agency immediately in cases of suspected child maltreatment. Findings suggestive of child maltreatment include signs of physical abuse, such as bruising, multiple fractures at different stages of healing, and scald burns. The presence of symmetrical sharply demarcated bullous lesions on this child's arms is highly suggestive of scald burns as a result of deliberate immersion in hot liquid. Accidental burns, such as spill burns resulting from hot liquid being spilled from a height, most often affect the head and neck in an asymmetrical pattern, unlike the symmetrical pattern seen here.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected child maltreatment, physicians are legally required to immediately notify the appropriate provincial child welfare agency to ensure the child's safety.

D) INCORRECT:

Although conducting a forensic interview to obtain further evidence may become necessary in the future, ensuring the child's safety is the most appropriate next step in management and should, therefore, take precedence. While physicians should perform a basic initial interview with verbal children, a forensic interview with a 2-year-old girl should be performed by professionals who have been trained in the field of child maltreatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Scheduling a follow-up examination is not indicated at this time. Instead, ensuring the child's safety is the most appropriate next step in management and should, therefore, take precedence.
questions.hint: Symmetrical, sharply demarcated lesions in a zebra-like pattern (intermittent stripes of normal skin with sparing of the flexion lines) are highly suggestive of immersion burns. Since both parents deny a recent history of trauma, the suspicion of child maltreatment is warranted.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-month-old boy in the emergency department. His mother reports an 8-hour history of difficulty feeding and decreased arousability, which began after he rolled over and fell from the bed. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are regions of purple discoloration in the T4–T10 dermatomes bilaterally and tense fontanelles. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral retinal hemorrhages. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial meningitis is typically accompanied by altered mental status (AMS), which, in infants, can manifest subtly with symptoms ranging from irritability to lethargy. Although this patient's decreased arousability indicates acute AMS, he does not have fever or signs of meningism. This patient's presentation should raise concern for nonaccidental trauma.

B) INCORRECT:

Common manifestations of a basilar skull fracture include periorbital ecchymosis with CSF rhinorrhea, CSF otorrhea, mastoid ecchymosis, and otorrhagia, which are not seen in this patient. Therefore, a skull base fracture is highly unlikely in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

An epidural hematoma usually results from rupture of the middle meningeal artery due to a traumatic skull fracture. Although this patient has evidence of altered mental status (decreased feeding and arousability), and it is likely that he sustained some form of head trauma, the fundoscopic findings would be less likely to occur in patients with epidural hematoma. Furthermore, epidural hematomas are not the most common type of intracranial hemorrhage in cases of pediatric nonaccidental trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Lobar hemorrhage is associated with cerebral amyloid angiopathy. This type of hemorrhage is typically seen in adults. This pediatric patient was most likely injured as a result of nonaccidental trauma, which does not typically cause lobar hemorrhage.

E) CORRECT:

Subdural hematomas are the most common type of intracranial hemorrhage in infants with shaken baby syndrome (SBS). In SBS, violent shaking of the baby results in whiplash and rapid rotational head movements, which lead to tearing of the intracerebral bridging veins and diffuse axonal injury. Other characteristic physical examination findings in children with SBS include irritability, lethargy, retinal hemorrhages (due to rupture of the retinal veins), and bulging fontanelles, all of which are seen here. Additional injuries that indicate child abuse include bruises to the upper torso (like the purple discoloration in the T4–T10 dermatomes seen in this patient that is most likely due to a forceful grip), posterior rib fractures, fractures at multiple stages of healing, and complex, long bone fractures (e.g., spiral humerus fractures).

Any case of suspected child abuse should be immediately reported to Child Protective Services.

Key learning point: Subdural hematoma with retinal hemorrhages and bruising in infants strongly suggests nonaccidental trauma such as shaken baby syndrome, requiring immediate evaluation for child abuse.
questions.hint: Infants do not begin to roll on their own until the age of 4–6 months. Nonaccidental trauma in children should be suspected when an inconsistent history is given by the caretaker, such as the claim that a 2-month-old infant rolled off a bed.

questions.text: You are seeing an 18-month-old girl who has not moved her left arm for the past day. Her mother does not recall any specific trauma but mentions that her daughter began walking 3 months ago and still falls frequently. On examination, there is swelling of the left upper arm and pain with passive movement. Radiography shows a spiral fracture of the left humerus. Which one of the following is the best next step in evaluating her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe vitamin D deficiency (when it results in osteomalacia) can lead to overt or occult fractures among children who are not the victims of physical abuse. Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a rare genetic bone disorder that is inherited through an autosomal dominant pattern, although sporadic mutations can occur. The most common form of OI is type 1, which accounts for approximately 80% of cases. Patients with OI or severe osteomalacia typically present with other findings on physical and radiological examinations by 18 months of age. Undertaking an evaluation for bone disorders such as these may be appropriate after taking a complete history and performing a detailed physical examination; however, testing for these conditions is not the most appropriate first step for a child who has been newly diagnosed with a seemingly pathologic fracture.

Furthermore, one should keep in mind that children with underlying medical disorders including bone disorders can also be victims of abuse and should be evaluated appropriately for that despite the presence of a possible alternative diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe vitamin D deficiency (when it results in osteomalacia) can lead to overt or occult fractures among children who are not the victims of physical abuse. Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a rare genetic bone disorder that is inherited through an autosomal dominant pattern, although sporadic mutations can occur. The most common form of OI is type 1, which accounts for approximately 80% of cases. Patients with OI or severe osteomalacia typically present with other findings on physical and radiological examinations by 18 months of age. Undertaking an evaluation for bone disorders such as these may be appropriate after taking a complete history and performing a detailed physical examination; however, testing for these conditions is not the most appropriate first step for a child who has been newly diagnosed with a seemingly pathologic fracture.

Furthermore, one should keep in mind that children with underlying medical disorders including bone disorders can also be victims of abuse and should be evaluated appropriately for that despite the presence of a possible alternative diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone scans can be useful in the evaluation of fractures related to physical abuse, but they often require sedation in infants and young children and are not the best next step in evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Bone scans can be useful in the evaluation of fractures related to physical abuse, but they often require sedation in infants and young children and are not the best next step in evaluation.

E) CORRECT:

An unexplained spiral humeral fracture in this child is concerning for physical abuse. Accidental spiral humeral shaft fractures are not common in young children. The mechanism of injury results from grabbing the upper arm and twisting.

When a child younger than 2 years of age is a suspected victim of physical abuse, the next step in evaluation is a skeletal survey to look for additional occult fractures, which may indicate prior injury or abuse. The skeletal survey should be repeated 2 weeks later to assess healing and appearance of nondisplaced fractures that were not previously identified. When abdominal trauma is being considered, appropriate testing can include liver function tests as well as measurement of amylase and lipase levels. When head trauma is considered, CT of the head is appropriate.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate for occult fractures in a child younger than 2 years of age who is a suspected victim of physical abuse is a skeletal survey.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-week-old boy who is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after his mother had difficulty awakening him for a feed. His mother reports that he has been cared for by a babysitter during the day since she returned to work. The babysitter noted that he has been vomiting more frequently and has seemed fussy over the past 2 days. His vital signs are stable. On examination, he is lethargic, hypotonic, and pale. There is a 1.5-cm ecchymosis on his left ear and a 5-cm x 4-cm cephalohematoma on the posterior parietal region of the skull. A CT of the head is provided. After airway stabilization and neurosurgery consultation, which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Notification of the provincial child welfare agency.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoprecipitate may be considered in clinical scenarios where the patient has significant bleeding. It is most helpful in low fibrinogen states. If a congenital bleeding disorder such as hemophilia A or hemophilia B is suspected, giving the patient a dose of the missing factor is more beneficial. A congenital bleeding disorder in the absence of trauma would not cause a skull fracture.

B) INCORRECT:

Retinal hemorrhages can be one of the earliest signs of intracranial injury in NAT. This patient is at risk for retinal hemorrhages, and an ophthalmologic consultation early in the hospital course is critical, but it is not the most appropriate next step.

C) INCORRECT:

Although an infection involving the central nervous system may cause symptoms similar to this patient’s (typically fever, vomiting, and altered mental status), the CT scan in this case shows a skull fracture with an extra-axial hematoma, highly suggestive of NAT. A lumbar puncture would not add diagnostic value and could put the patient at greater risk given his current clinical instability.

D) CORRECT:

The presence of a skull fracture and an extra-axial hematoma is highly concerning for abusive head trauma. Nonaccidental trauma (NAT) should be considered when children present with unexplained or poorly explained injuries that are not consistent with their level of development or when there appears to be a delay in seeking care for concerning symptoms. Lack of recognition of NAT can result in severe morbidity or, possibly, death. Notification of law enforcement authorities and the appropriate provincial child welfare agency is a critical next step once the patient is stabilized.

Radiologic evaluation of NAT includes the following components:

• CT of the brain (acutely) or MRI of the brain (if the patient is asymptomatic) to assess for intracranial injury
• A complete skeletal survey to assess for other fractures
• CT of the abdomen and pelvis if intra-abdominal organ damage is suspected

Nonradiologic evaluation of NAT should include a full physical examination with the child unclothed, a fundoscopic examination to assess for retinal hemorrhages, basic laboratory testing such as a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, coagulation studies in cases with bleeding, and hepatic and pancreatic enzyme levels to assess for intra-abdominal injury.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected child abuse, the appropriate provincial child welfare agency should be notified.

Stabilizing the patient is of utmost importance. Patients with depressed mental status require intubation for airway protection before imaging is conducted. Hypertension, bradycardia, and erratic breathing may suggest impending brainstem herniation. Consulting the neurosurgery team, administering hypertonic saline or mannitol, and elevating the head of the bed may reduce the likelihood of this complication.

E) INCORRECT:

A single whole-body radiograph (“babygram”) is simply one anteroposterior view of an infant that includes the chest, abdomen, and extremities. It is an inadequate study and is not sensitive or specific enough to identify the bones in detail and rule out occult fractures. A complete skeletal survey is the best method to identify fractures in infants and children <2 years of age whose presentation is concerning for physical abuse. A complete skeletal survey entails multiple images of the entire body (approximately 20 images), which may reveal additional acute as well as healing fractures that may not have been part of a patient’s initial presenting complaint.
questions.hint: Symptoms of abusive head trauma in infants can be nonspecific and may include poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, fussiness, hypotonia, and seizures. The finding of the left-ear bruise on this nonmobile infant is a sentinel injury for abuse.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to your clinic by her mother because of bed-wetting over the past 3 weeks. Her mother is concerned as the school has reported that her daughter has been acting out in class and making inappropriate jokes. On examination, she has a thin body habitus with no axillary or pubic hair. There are a few pink, fleshy papules measuring 3–5 mm on the vulva. There is no vulvar erythema or discharge. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Interview the patient and mother separately.
Reassure the mother and follow up with the patient.
Recommend scheduled voiding and fluid restriction at night.
Perform a urine dipstick test and measure serum glucose.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This child shows signs of sexual abuse, for which a well-documented patient interview is often the most important piece of evidence. In over 90% of cases, the perpetrator is an individual known to the child or their family. Therefore, it is important to interview the child separately from the parent to allow for a neutral and honest conversation. Furthermore, girls aged 9–12 years are at increased risk for sexual abuse. Behavioral changes that should raise concern for sexual abuse include sexually acting-out, sexual remarks that are inconsistent with age, problems at school, aggression, regression (e.g., nocturnal enuresis), eating or sleep disturbances, and depression. Medical conditions that should raise concern for sexual abuse include sexually transmitted infections (e.g., condylomata acuminata), pregnancies, recurrent urinary tract infections, and anogenital or oral trauma.

The threshold for investigating any suspected case of child abuse should be very low. The patient interview is followed by a careful physical examination and screening for STIs. Subsequently, the physician must notify the appropriate provincial child welfare authority to protect the safety of the child and to ensure further investigation (including a forensic interview).

Key learning point: Behavioral changes and genital findings in a child should prompt separate interviews to assess for possible sexual abuse before considering other causes of symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassuring the mother and following up with the patient is indicated in primary enuresis (the patient never achieved continence) up to 5 years of age whereas this patient has new-onset secondary enuresis (the patient previously achieved continence) at 9 years of age, which requires further workup. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.

C) INCORRECT:

Scheduled voiding and fluid restriction at night are indicated as first-line therapy for nocturnal enuresis that is not caused by another medical condition in children older than 5 years of age. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.

D) INCORRECT:

Performing a urine dipstick test and measuring serum glucose is indicated for ruling out type 1 diabetes. Secondary enuresis and nocturia, both of which are seen here, may occur in children with type 1 diabetes. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before she is assessed for type 1 diabetes.

E) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin therapy is indicated as second-line therapy for nocturnal enuresis that is not caused by another medical condition in children older than 5 years of age. This patient's additional behavioral changes and physical findings, however, raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.
questions.hint: This 9-year-old girl has new-onset nocturnal enuresis, behavioral changes, and features suggestive of condylomata acuminata.

questions.text: A 15-month-old girl presents with irritability and lethargy that began yesterday. Her mother reports that the child fell from a couch 3 days ago but appeared well at the time. Examination reveals a lethargic child with a tense anterior fontanelle. CT of the head shows acute and chronic subdural hematomas with subarachnoid hemorrhage. Ophthalmologic examination demonstrates bilateral retinal hemorrhages. Vital signs are stable for age. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer mannitol for increased intracranial pressure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A skeletal survey is indicated for all children under 2 years of age with suspected abusive head trauma to assess for additional injuries. The skeletal survey can be obtained once the patient is stabilized.

B) INCORRECT:

Mandatory reporting is required once abuse is suspected, but it must occur after or concurrently with life-saving interventions.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – The findings of mixed-age subdural hematomas, retinal hemorrhages, and an inconsistent history strongly suggest abusive head trauma. Urgent neurosurgical consultation is required for management of possible elevated intracranial pressure and to guide further treatment. Initiate mandated CPS reporting once clinically stable.

D) INCORRECT:

While CBC and coagulation studies may be indicated to rule out bleeding disorders as a cause of intracranial hemorrhage, they are not the initial priority when the clinical presentation strongly suggests abusive head trauma. The combination of acute and chronic subdural hematomas with retinal hemorrhages is highly concerning for abuse.

E) INCORRECT:

The child is hemodynamically stable with normal vital signs, and there are no immediate signs of impending herniation that would require emergency medical intervention.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by his father for evaluation of lethargy and poor feeding. The father states the infant rolled off the couch this morning but seemed fine initially. The infant appears irritable with a high-pitched cry. Physical examination shows a tense and bulging anterior fontanelle. There are scattered bruises of varying ages on his trunk and upper arms. A non-contrast head CT is ordered. Which of the following findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An epidural hematoma is a collection of blood between the dura mater and the skull. It is typically caused by a direct blow to the head that results in a skull fracture and tearing of a meningeal artery, most commonly the middle meningeal artery. While possible in cases of abuse involving direct impact, it is much less common than the injury pattern caused by a shaking mechanism. On CT, it appears as a lens-shaped (lentiform) collection of blood.

B) INCORRECT:

Traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage can occur with head trauma, including abusive head trauma, as small cortical vessels are torn. While often present along with other injuries, an isolated or predominant traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage is not the most likely primary finding in this clinical scenario.

C) INCORRECT:

Diffuse cerebral edema is a common and severe finding in abusive head trauma, often resulting from hypoxic-ischemic injury secondary to the primary trauma or associated apnea. While it contributes significantly to the increased intracranial pressure, it is often a secondary finding.

D) INCORRECT:

A linear skull fracture can result from a direct impact to the head, and its presence in an infant with a questionable history should raise suspicion for abuse. However, a simple linear fracture alone would not typically cause the severe neurologic signs of increased intracranial pressure seen in this patient, such as a bulging fontanelle and lethargy. The primary injury from a shaking mechanism is intracranial, not necessarily osseous.

E) CORRECT:

Abusive head trauma is caused by violent acceleration-deceleration and rotational forces that cause tearing of the bridging veins as they cross the subdural space. This leads to a subdural hematoma, the hallmark intracranial finding in AHT. On a non-contrast head CT, this appears as a crescent-shaped hyperdensity that can cross suture lines.

Other classic findings in AHT include retinal hemorrhages and fractures of the long bones or ribs.
questions.hint: This infant's clinical signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as lethargy, a bulging fontanelle, and a high-pitched cry, are highly concerning for abusive head trauma (AHT), also known as shaken baby syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by his mother for evaluation of a seizure. The mother reports the infant was "fussy all day" and then had a 2-minute episode of generalized tonic-clonic activity. She denies any recent falls or trauma. On examination, the infant is lethargic. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, and respirations are 40/min. The anterior fontanelle is full. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral retinal hemorrhages. A non-contrast head CT shows a crescent-shaped hyperdensity along the cerebral convexity, consistent with a subdural hematoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital and consult child protective services
Arrange for emergency neurosurgical consultation for evacuation
Confront the mother about the inconsistent history
Discharge home with close primary care follow-up in 24 hours

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The immediate priorities for a suspected non-accidental head injury in a child are medical stabilization and ensuring the child's safety. Admission to the hospital is necessary for neurologic monitoring, management of increased intracranial pressure, and seizure control. Simultaneously, a consultation with child protective services (CPS) is a legal and ethical mandate for any health care provider who suspects child abuse. This step initiates a formal investigation to protect the child from further harm and is the most critical overarching action.

B) INCORRECT:

A neurosurgical consultation is an important component of this infant's care because of the subdural hematoma. However, not all subdural hematomas require surgical evacuation. The decision to operate depends on the size of the bleed, the degree of mass effect, and the patient's neurologic status. Although this consultation will be necessary, it is not the most appropriate initial step in management.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the history is inconsistent with the clinical findings, confronting the caregiver is not the role of the medical provider and can be counterproductive. Such an action may cause the caregiver to become defensive, leave with the child against medical advice, or interfere with the subsequent formal investigation.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharging this infant would be inappropriate and dangerous. This patient has a life-threatening intracranial injury requiring inpatient monitoring and management. Furthermore, given the high suspicion for abuse, returning the child to a potentially unsafe environment would place them at extreme risk for further injury or death. This action would constitute a significant breach of the provider's duty to protect the patient.
questions.hint: This infant's presentation with a subdural hematoma, bilateral retinal hemorrhages, and a history inconsistent with the severity of the injury is classic for abusive head trauma (AHT), formerly known as shaken baby syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a painful rash on her hands and lower arms. According to the mother, she developed blisters and redness on her arms 2 days ago. Both parents claim there is no recent history of fever, itching, or trauma. Physical examination shows erythema and multiple fluid-filled bullae on the hands and arms up to the elbows with intermittent stripes of normal skin seen on the palmar aspect of the hand. The lesions are symmetrical in distribution and are sharply delineated. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action?

choices.text: Schedule a follow-up examination for further evaluation
Ask both parents to leave the examination room to perform a forensic interview of the child
Obtain a biopsy specimen of the skin lesions for histopathological examination

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scheduling a follow-up examination is not indicated at this time. Instead, ensuring the child's safety is the most appropriate next step in management and should, therefore, take precedence.

B) CORRECT:

Healthcare professionals must notify Child Protective Services (CPS) immediately in cases of suspected child maltreatment. Findings suggestive of child maltreatment include signs of physical abuse, such as bruising, multiple fractures at different stages of healing, and scald burns. The presence of symmetrical sharply demarcated bullous lesions on this child's arms is highly suggestive of scald burns as a result of deliberate immersion in hot liquid. Accidental burns, such as spill burns resulting from hot liquid being spilled from a height, most often affect the head and neck in an asymmetrical pattern, unlike the symmetrical pattern seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Although conducting a forensic interview to obtain further evidence may become necessary in the future, ensuring the child's safety is the most appropriate next step in management and should, therefore, take precedence. While healthcare professionals should perform a basic initial interview with verbal children, a forensic interview with a 2-year-old girl should be performed by professionals who have been trained in the field of child maltreatment.

D) INCORRECT:

The child's skin findings most likely resulted from trauma caused by immersion of her arms in hot liquid. However, both parents deny a recent history of trauma, which should raise suspicion that the patient's history was fabricated by her parents. At this point, it is unlikely that talking to both parents individually will bring clarification. Moreover, confronting the parents with doubts about the truthfulness of their statements could lead to them avoiding further contact with healthcare professionals and subsequently place the child at risk of further injury and maltreatment.

E) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis of immersion burns can be made clinically and does not require histopathological examination of the affected skin. Instead, ensuring the patient's safety is the most appropriate next step in management.
questions.hint: Symmetrical, sharply demarcated lesions in a zebra-like pattern (intermittent stripes of normal skin with sparing of the flexion lines) are highly suggestive of immersion burns. Since both parents deny a recent history of trauma, the suspicion of child maltreatment is warranted.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought for a routine examination. On inspection, there are multiple bruises in different stages of healing on his upper arms and back. The child appears tense, avoids eye contact, and clings to his mother, who gives inconsistent explanations about the injuries. Vital signs are within normal limits, and the child denies any pain or distress. You are concerned about possible neglect or abuse. What is the most appropriate next step to foster rapport and gather accurate information?

choices.text: Arrange for child protective services to be present during the conversation to ensure official oversight from the outset
Continue the examination with the mother present, relying on her account to clarify the child’s injuries
Speak with the child alone in a comfortable setting, using age-appropriate language and open-ended questions
Confront the mother directly about suspected abuse to address the inconsistent explanations early

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Involving child protective services immediately may interfere with establishing a trusting environment for the child. The presence of external authorities can increase the child's anxiety and inhibit honest disclosure. Speaking with the child separately allows for candid dialogue, and external agencies are typically involved after sufficient rapport and history have been established.

B) INCORRECT:

Relying solely on the mother's account is inappropriate given the child's signs of discomfort and the mother's inconsistent explanations. The presence of multiple bruises at different stages of healing raises concern for non-accidental trauma. Interviewing the child alone is crucial to foster open communication and reduce the risk of the child withholding information due to fear or coercion.

C) CORRECT:

In cases of suspected child maltreatment, it is essential to create a safe and non-intimidating environment for the child. Speaking with the child alone allows for a confidential conversation, reducing the influence of potentially implicated caregivers. Using age-appropriate language ensures clarity and comfort, while open-ended questions encourage the child to share information freely. This approach aligns with best practices in pediatric care, prioritizing the child's comfort and promoting honest disclosure.

Key learning point: Building rapport with a child during a medical consultation is crucial, especially in cases of suspected neglect or abuse, to ensure the child feels safe and comfortable to share information.

D) INCORRECT:

Directly confronting the mother about suspected abuse can undermine trust and provoke a defensive reaction, limiting further disclosure. A confrontational approach may lead the caregiver to withhold important details and impede the collection of a comprehensive history. Establishing a supportive and nonjudgmental environment is more effective for accurate information gathering.

questions.text: A 2-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of an 8-hour history of difficulty feeding and decreased arousability. His mother says that the symptoms began after he rolled over and fell from the bed. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows regions of purple discoloration in the T4–T10 dermatomes bilaterally and tense fontanelles. Fundoscopy shows bilateral optic disc swelling with dot-and-blot hemorrhages extending to the ora serrata. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Common manifestations of a basilar skull fracture include periorbital ecchymosis with CSF rhinorrhea, CSF otorrhea, mastoid ecchymosis, and otorrhagia, which are not seen in this patient. Therefore, a skull base fracture is highly unlikely in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Lobar hemorrhage is associated with cerebral amyloid angiopathy. This type of hemorrhage is typically seen in adults. This pediatric patient was most likely injured as a result of nonaccidental trauma, which does not typically cause lobar hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

An epidural hematoma usually results from rupture of the middle meningeal artery due to a traumatic skull fracture. Although this patient has evidence of altered mental status (decreased feeding and arousability), and it is likely that he sustained some form of head trauma, the fundoscopic findings would be less likely to occur in patients with epidural hematoma. Furthermore, epidural hematomas are not the most common type of intracranial hemorrhage in cases of pediatric nonaccidental trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacterial meningitis is typically accompanied by altered mental status (AMS), which, in infants, can manifest subtly with symptoms ranging from irritability to lethargy. Although this patient's decreased arousability indicates acute AMS, he does not have fever or signs of meningism. This patient's presentation should raise concern for nonaccidental trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Periventricular hemorrhage (PVH) is a major cause of neurological disabilities and most commonly occurs in preterm infants due to germinal matrix hemorrhage. However, this boy was born at full term. Furthermore, symptoms would be expected to arise within the first 1–5 days of life, not 2 months after birth. This patient was most likely injured as a result of nonaccidental trauma, which does not typically lead to PVH.

F) CORRECT:

Subdural hematomas are the most common type of intracranial hemorrhage in infants with shaken baby syndrome (SBS). In SBS, violent shaking of the baby results in whiplash and rapid rotational head movements, which lead to tearing of the intracerebral bridging veins and diffuse axonal injury. Other characteristic physical examination findings in children with SBS include irritability, lethargy, retinal hemorrhages (due to rupture of the retinal veins), and bulging fontanelles, all of which are seen here. Additional injuries that indicate child abuse include bruises to the upper torso (like the purple discoloration in the T4–T10 dermatomes seen in this patient that is most likely due to a forceful grip), posterior rib fractures, fractures at multiple stages of healing, and complex, long bone fractures (e.g., spiral humerus fractures).

Any case of suspected child abuse should be immediately reported to Child Protective Services.
questions.hint: Infants do not begin to roll on their own until the age of 4–6 months. Nonaccidental trauma in children should be suspected when an inconsistent history is given by the caretaker, such as the claim that a 2-month-old infant rolled off a bed.
